Authors: Sendra M., Sutrisno R., Harianata J., Suhartono D., Asmani A.B.
Title: Enhanced Latent Semantic Analysis by considering mistyped words in automated essay scoring
Source title: 2016 International Conference on Informatics and Computing, ICIC 2016
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, School of Computer Science, Jakarta, Indonesia; Bina Nusantara University, Language Center, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Sendra, M., Bina Nusantara University, School of Computer Science, Jakarta, Indonesia; Sutrisno, R., Bina Nusantara University, School of Computer Science, Jakarta, Indonesia; Harianata, J., Bina Nusantara University, School of Computer Science, Jakarta, Indonesia; Suhartono, D., Bina Nusantara University, School of Computer Science, Jakarta, Indonesia; Asmani, A.B., Bina Nusantara University, Language Center, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: In this paper, we present an approach to consider the mistyped words which frequently occur in an essay. Not all the mistyped words are totally wrong. If they are caused by human errors, we should look further to handle it. Thus, enhanced version of Latent Semantic Analysis (LSA) is proposed. LSA is enhanced by calculating the value of mistyped words before constructing the term document matrix. Essays which are scored consists of 119 English essays of student's writing assignment while several essays as gold standard are made by experts. All of the essays have been scored manually by the human grader. Enhanced LSA gives the closeness level of 0.242 to human judgment, while LSA indicates the closeness level of 0.244 to human judgment. Unfortunately, Enhanced LSA cannot outperform GLSA which is one of current methods. The experiment result indicates that Enhanced LSA by considering mistyped words has a better closeness value to human judgment compared with LSA. © 2016 IEEE.
Author Keywords: enhanced LSA; Latent Semantic Analysis; mistyped words; term document matrix
Index Keywords: Matrix algebra; Automated essay scoring; Document matrices; enhanced LSA; Gold standards; Human judgments; Latent Semantic Analysis; mistyped words; Writing assignments; Semantics
References: Hyland, K., (2004) Disciplinary Discourses: Social Interactions in Academic Writing, , Michigan: The University of Michigan Press; Wild, F., Stahl, C., Stermsek, G., Neumann, G., Parameters Driving Effectiveness of Automated Essay Scoring with LSA (2005) Proceedings of the 9th CAA Conference Loughborough; Dikli, S., Automated Essay Scoring (2006) Turkish Online Journal of Distance Education, 7 (5), pp. 49-62; Dikli, S., An Overview of Automated Scoring of Essays (2006) Journal of Technology, Learning, and Assessment, 5 (1); Landauer, T.K., Foltz, P.W., Laham, D., Introduction to Latent Semantic Analysis (1998) Discourse Processes, 25, pp. 259-284; Islam, M.M., Hoque, S.M.L., Automated Essay Scoring Using Generalized Latent Semantic Analysis (2012) Journal of Computers, 7 (3); Hofmann, T., Probabilistic Latent Semantic Analysis (1999) Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence, UAI"99, Stockholm; Blei, D.M., Ng, A.Y., Jordan, M.I., Latent Dirichlet Allocation (2003) Journal of Machine Learning Research, 3, pp. 993-1022; Valenti, S., Neri, F., Cucchiarelli, A., An Overview of Current Research on Automated Essay Grading (2003) Journal of Information Technology Education, 2

Title: Needs analysis for academic operation staff at binus university in facing world class operational excellence
Affiliations: Language Center, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Asmani, A.B., Language Center, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Wiharja, C.K., Language Center, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The purpose of the research project was to describe the needs analysis of Academic Operation Staff at BINUS University in using English when they had to communicate with international guests. The research project applied the combined approach of quantitative and qualitative methods, and thus depended on numerical and verbal data. The research project examined the numeric data in questionnaire format, and showed the frequency and percentages of each given statement. It also examined the verbal data in interview format, and explained the linguistic features. The quantitative results showed that the conversation patterns between the staff and foreign guests; in this case international students and teachers, could happen in two big domains of “face-to-face” and phone interactions. The qualitative results showed that the English proficiency of these staff was mostly at beginner’s level, and thus the pocket book should be designed with simple sentence structure, common vocabulary, and easy pronunciation way. If possible, all language functions presented in the book should be chosen and thought of carefully, so as to not differ too much from their local language schemata. © 2017 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Academic operation staff; Language functions; Needs analysis

Title: Leadership practices to support TESOL program for EFL students—a case study at BINUS university
Affiliations: Language Center, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Asmani, A.B., Language Center, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Wiharja, C.K., Language Center, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: As more undergraduate students swarmed into higher education in EFL (English as a Foreign Language)-based countries, e.g., Indonesia, where English was still considered foreign, they therefore had to take English courses as part of their academic learning. Although there were many evidences indicating a strong link between effective leadership and successful TESOL (Teaching English to Speakers of Other languages) program, there was still a lack of studies of leadership into the field. This article investigated leadership practices which supported TESOL program for undergraduate EFL students at BINUS University, where English courses were compulsory and EFL students were the majority. Effective leadership practices for TESOL were highlighted, which were setting goals and objectives, allowing leaders to be pioneers, providing TESOL professional training, and facilitating TESOL program. Obstacles to these practices were also found, such as the lack of shared information network and the prevailing minor views on TESOL program, in which members were considered having the low status. The article concluded that as EFL students were growing in number in the university to meet their future targets at international contexts, the need and focus on developing leadership practices and resources to support TESOL program was inevitable. © 2017 American Scientific Publishers. All rights reserved
Author Keywords: BINUS University; EFL students; Leadership practices; TESOL program

Title: Correlation analysis between TOEFL® iBT reading and academic writing scores among binus university sophomores
Affiliations: Language Center, BINUS University, Jl. Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Palmerah, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Asmani, A.B., Language Center, BINUS University, Jl. Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Palmerah, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Wiharja, C.K., Language Center, BINUS University, Jl. Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Palmerah, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The purpose of the research project is to find out whether BINUS university sophomores’ TOEFL® iBT passive skill scores of Reading were correlated with those of active skill scores of Writing. The research project is expected to result in the best teaching technique of delivering English courses at BINUS University by using alternative approaches of integrated or independent skills. The research project applied the descriptive approach of quantitative method, and thus depended on numerical data. The research project examined the data under two paired scores of the same class groups. The set of scores was to compare the reading scores with the writing results. Then, the degree of correlation of the pair was tested so as to find its significance. Interpretation and explanation of data was made based on the statistical results by using correlation research analysis. Based on the statistical results, it can be concluded that the scores of the receptive skill of TOEFL® iBT Reading were significantly correlated with those of the productive skill of Academic Writing, and there was a moderate linear relationship between these paired scores. © 2016 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Academic writing; Correlation; TOEFL® iBT reading
References: Asmani, A., (2015) Lingua Cultura, 8, p. 85; Harmer, J., (2007) The Practice of English Language Teaching, , Pearson Education Limited, Essex; Liddicoat, A., (1997) Academic Communication across Disciplines and Cultures, pp. 12-23. , edited by Z. Authors: Wonowidjojo G., Hartono M.S., Frendy, Suhartono D., Asmani A.B.
Title: Automated essay scoring by combining syntactically enhanced latent semantic analysis and coreference resolution
Source title: 2016 6th International Workshop on Computer Science and Engineering, WCSE 2016
Affiliations: Computer Science Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; English Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Wonowidjojo, G., Computer Science Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Hartono, M.S., Computer Science Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Frendy, Computer Science Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Suhartono, D., Computer Science Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Asmani, A.B., English Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The objective of this research is to measure how much syntactic information (in the form of word order) and Coreference Resolution affect the result of Automated Essay Scoring (AES) using Latent Semantic Analysis (LSA). To incorporate the syntactic information, Syntactically Enhanced LSA (SELSA) is used, whilst Stanford CoreNLP Natural Language Processing Toolkit is used for the Coreference Resolution. To evaluate the results, we calculate the average absolute difference between the system score and human score for each essay. Based on the results, we can conclude that syntactic information, when combined with Coreference Resolution, do not have higher correlation to human score than LSA (an average absolute difference of 0.15748 as opposed to LSA's 0.12597). But interestingly, the two techniques work better when they are used together, rather than when they are used separately. We also develop a new algorithm to calculate the scores, with a better average absolute difference, which is as high as 0.08969.
Author Keywords: Automated essay scoring; Coreference resolution; Syntactically enhanced latent semantic analysis; Word order
Index Keywords: Automation; Semantics; Syntactics; Absolute difference; Automated essay scoring; Co-reference resolutions; Latent Semantic Analysis; NAtural language processing; Stanford; Syntactic information; Word orders; Natural language processing systems

Title: Needs analysis for taxi drivers for independent english learning
Affiliations: Language Center, BINUS University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; English Department, BINUS University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Asmani, A.B., Language Center, BINUS University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia, English Department, BINUS University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Wijaya, C.K., Language Center, BINUS University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The purpose of the research project was to describe the needs analysis of the taxi drivers in using English when they had to communicate with international guests. The research project was expected to produce a pocket-sized book for taxi drivers to allow them to practice English independently. The research project applied the combined approach of quantitative and qualitative methods, and thus depended on numerical and verbal data. The research project examined the numeric data in questionnaire format and showed the frequency and percentages of each given statement. It also examined the verbal data in interview format, and explained the linguistic features. The quantitative results showed that the conversation pattern between a taxi driver and a foreign guest was best represented by six different stages, which consisted of beginning, highway, address searching, external emergency, internal emergency, and apologizing. The qualitative results showed that the English of taxi drivers should use simple sentences, common words, and pronunciation which had a close resemblance with the local language, if possible. © 2015 American Scientific Publishers.
Author Keywords: Independent english learning; Needs analysis; Taxi drivers
References: Ary, D., Jacobs, L.C., Razavieh, A., Sorensen, C., (2006) Introduction to Research in Education, , Thomson Wadsworth, USA; Cohen, L., Manion, L., (2000) Research Methods in Education, , Routledge Farmer, London; Connor, U., Upton, T., (2004) Introduction, Discourse in the Professions: Perspectives from Corpus Linguistics, pp. 1-8. , edited by U.
